pages.title: Sheetster
pages.text:
{{ Infobox Software
| name                   = [[Extentech|Extentech Inc.]]
| logo                   = [[File:Sheetster logo.png|Sheetster Logo]]
| screenshot = Sheetster screenshot.png
| screenshot size = 250px
| developer              = [[Extentech|Extentech, Inc.]]
| latest_release_version = Sheetster Version 1.4
| latest_release_date    = {{release_date|2009|10|27}}
| latest_preview_version = 1.0
| latest_preview_date    = {{release_date|2009|01|27}}
| operating_system       = [[Cross-platform]]
| programming language   = [[Java (programming language)|Java]], [[JavaServer Pages|JSP]] and [[JavaScript]]
| genre                  = [[Spreadsheet]]
| license                = Professional Edition is commercial / proprietary, Community Edition is [[Apache v2]] 
| website                = {{URL|http://www.sheetster.com/}}
}}
'''Sheetster ''' is a [[GPL]] [[open-source software|open-source]] Web [[Spreadsheet]] and a [[Java (software platform)|Java]] Application Server created by [[Extentech|Extentech Inc]]. The product was created for the enterprise and small and medium-sized businesses as an Open Source alternative to closed [[document management system]]s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://asterisk.tmcnet.com/topics/open-source/articles/66752-extentech-alfresco-intro-integrated-open-source-web-spreadsheet.htm|title=Extentech and Alfresco Intro Integrated Open Source Web Spreadsheet Solution |last=Shrivastava|first=Anshu|date=October 15, 2009|work=TMCnet|accessdate=2009-10-27}}</ref>

== History ==
Built by [[Extentech|Extentech Inc]], a developer of Java spreadsheet and development tools, Sheetster BETA was made available to the public on June 8, 2007.

== Features ==
* Output to PDF
* Total Compatibility with Excel 1997–2007 Files (BIFF8 and XLSX Spreadsheets)
* Embed YouTube videos in your Spreadsheets
* Publish Spreadsheets as RSS with R3S
* Instant Web2.0 Apps with Forms, Charts, and Macros
* Role-based security and sharing<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sheetster.com/ |title=Sheetster Features|accessdate=January 8, 2010}}</ref>

Sheetster runs on the [[ExtenXLS]] [[Java (programming language)]] Spreadsheet [[Software development kit|SDK]] and includes:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sourceforge.net/projects/sheetster/ |title=Sheetster Web Spreadsheet|accessdate=2009-10-27}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable"
|-
! Sheetster Web Spreadsheet
! ExtenXLS Java Spreadsheet SDK
! Cellbinder Automation API
! Spreadsheet Automation Server
|-
| Source Included/GPL 
| Customizable Java Swing [[GUI]]
| [[REST API]] [[JSON]]/[[XML]]/[[HTML]]/[[Comma-separated values|CSV]]/[[Microsoft Excel#File formats|XLS]] output
| Object-Relational Mapper and Query Builder
|-
| Document chat
| Named ranges
| Secure content management system
| Embeddable live data charts
|-
| Macros, forms, and gadgets for web 2.0 [[database]] applications 
| [[Microsoft Excel|Excel]] 2007 compatibility
| Data Mapping API
| Collaboration, versioning, and access control<ref>{{cite news|url=http://extentech.sys-con.com/node/319430|title= Extentech Announces Release of Sheetster |last=Java News Desk|date=April 4, 2007|work=Sys-Con|accessdate=2009-10-27}}</ref> 
|-
|}

The Sheetster administration console allows for the design of relational data objects using a visual query designer and object-relational mapper. The RESTful API accepts data from a variety of sources, and outputs data-mapped spreadsheet objects in a variety of formats including JSON, XML, and as Excel-compatible XLS. 
Sheetster can be automated with macros and automatic data entry forms created from Excel cell ranges. Data Objects can be mapped to spreadsheet templates and output in a variety of formats:<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bx.businessweek.com/information-governance/view?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sramanamitra.com%2F2009%2F03%2F09%2Fdeal-radar-2009-extentech%2F|title=Ventana Research in Deal Radar 2009: Extentech Article Deal Radar 2009: Extentech |last=Mitra|first=Sramana|date=March 9, 2009|work=Ventana Research|accessdate=2009-10-27}}</ref>
* Excel 2007 Spreadsheet (.xlsx/.ooxml)
* Excel Binary Spreadsheet (.xls)CSV
* ExtenXLS XML Doc (.exml)
* Archive All Spreadsheets (.zip)
* [[XSLT]] Transform
* CSV

== Usage ==
[[File:Sheester screenshot megacomm.jpeg|thumb|alt=Sheetster Open Source Spreadsheet|A Sheetster Spreadsheet]]
Most common usages of sheetster:
* As a hosted web spreadsheet: [http://www.sheetster.com www.sheetster.com]
* As a web service embedded within other applications
* Spreadsheet calculations—used as secure formula engines within Web 2.0 and traditional client-server web applications.

== Storage ==
Sheetster can be stored in any database or file system of choice, such as:
* SaaS online access
* Local host server for offline access
* Behind the firewall
* On [[Amazon S3]]
[[File:Sheetster defined.png|thumb|alt=Sheetster Server Defined|Sheetster Server Defined]]

== Integration ==
Integration is achieved through the RESTful API which allows for publishing of data-mapped spreadsheet cells as web services. Sheetster provides integrated support for:
# Advanced server-based spreadsheet automation and functionality
# [http://www.alfresco.com/ Alfresco ECM]
# A REST API with JSON/XML/HTML/CSV/ and XLS output
# Sheetster Web Spreadsheet (source included)
# Built-in secure content management system
# ExtenXLS Java Spreadsheet SDK
# Customizable Java Swing administration GUI with Object-Relational Mapper and Query Builder

[http://extentech.com/uimodules/docs/docs_detail.jsp?showall=true&meme_id=2396 Integration guide]

Sheetster is available for download at [http://extentech.com/estore/product_detail.jsp?product_group_id=230&product_id=321 Extentech.com] and [http://sourceforge.net/projects/sheetster/ Sourceforge].

== Notes ==
{{Reflist}}

== References ==
* [http://ostatic.com/sheetster-open-source-web-spreadsheet ''Sheetster Open Source'', anonymous author]
* [http://www.wareprise.com/2009/10/19/how-to-open-and-edit-excel-2007-xlsx-file-online/ ''how-to-open-and-edit-excel-2007-xlsx-file-online'',October 19, 2009, Walsh, Ivan]
* [http://www.downloadsquad.com/2007/08/23/sheetster-web-based-spreadsheets/ ''Sheetster: Web based spreadsheets'',August 23, 2009, White, Peter]

==External links==
*[http://www.extentech.com/  Extentech]
*{{cite news|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2009/10/prweb3033394.htm|title=Extentech and Alfresco Partner to Deliver a Powerful Open Source Web Spreadsheet |date= October 14, 2009   |work=Press release|accessdate=2009-10-27}}
*[http://sourceforge.net/projects/sheetster/ Sourceforge]

pages.title: WikiCalc
pages.text:
{{lowercase}}
{{Infobox software
|name = wikiCalc
|latest_release_version = 1.0
|latest_release_date = {{Start date and age|2007|01|25}}
|operating_system = [[Cross-platform]]
|genre = [[Wiki]] / [[List of online spreadsheets|Online Spreadsheet]]
|license = [[GPL|GNU General Public License]]
|website = {{URL|http://www.softwaregarden.com/products/wikicalc/}}
|developer = [[Dan Bricklin]]
|}}
'''wikiCalc''' is a [[web application]], created by [[Dan Bricklin]], that allows for the creation and editing of [[spreadsheet]]s through a [[wiki]]-style user-editable interface. It is currently released as version 1.0 for use on Windows, Mac, Linux/Unix, and other platforms that can run the [[Perl]] language.

The product was envisioned in 2005 by Bricklin, who 27 years earlier created [[VisiCalc]], the first [[commerce|commercial]] spreadsheet program for the [[personal computer]]. Version Alpha 0.1 was released for [[alpha testing]] in November 2005. Version 1.0 was released on January 25, 2007. wikiCalc is written in the [[Perl]] programming language.

wikiCalc is released under the [[GNU General Public License]],<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.softwaregarden.com/products/wikicalc/
|title=wikiCalc home page
|quote=...released under the GPL 2.0 license...
}}</ref> and is thus [[free software]].

On June 8, 2006, Dan Bricklin and [[Socialtext]] announced a partnership which encompasses an exclusive distribution deal as well as a pledge for co-development.<ref>{{cite web|first=Michael|last=Arrington|authorlink=Michael Arrington|publisher=[[TechCrunch]]|url=https://techcrunch.com/2006/06/08/socialtextwikicalc-more-interesting-than-google-spreadsheets/|title=SocialText/wikiCalc: More Interesting Than Google Spreadsheets|date=2006-06-08|accessdate=2007-02-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://danbricklin.com/log/2006_04_05.htm#socialtext|title=wikiCalc Partnership with SocialText|first=Dan|last=Bricklin|authorlink=Dan Bricklin|publisher=DanBricklin.com|date=2006-06-09|accessdate=2007-02-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.socialtext.com/node/82|title=Socialtext Partners with Dan Bricklin on wikiCalc|publisher=[[Socialtext]]|first=Ross|last=Mayfield|authorlink=Ross Mayfield|date=2006-06-09|accessdate=2007-02-11}}</ref> The Socialtext version of the software is called [[SocialCalc]].

pages.title: EditGrid
pages.text:
{{Infobox software
| name                   = EditGrid
| logo                   = Editgrid-grey.png
| screenshot             = 
| caption                = Logo
| developer              = [[Team and Concepts]]
| released               = 2006
| programming language   = 
| operating system       = Any (Web-based application)
| language               = [[#Multilingualism|Multilingual (9)]]
| genre                  = Online spreadsheet
| license                = 
| website                = {{URL|http://www.editgrid.com}}
}}
'''EditGrid''' was a [[Web 2.0]] [[spreadsheet]] service, operated via [[Internet access]] ([[web-based application]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/editgrid_online_spreadsheet.php
 |title=EditGrid - New Online Spreadsheet, Better Than Google Spreadsheets
 |author=Richard MacManus and Gang Lu
 |publisher=[[ReadWriteWeb]]
 |date=2007-02-15
 |accessdate=2007-02-16
}}</ref> It offered both a [[Freeware|free-of-charge]] service to personal users and a [[Software as a service|subscription service]] to organisations and was available on a number of partner sites and channels.<ref>{{cite web
 |url         = http://blogs.zdnet.com/SAAS/?p=374
 |title       = EditGrid』s distinctive Office 2.0 business model
 |author      = Phil Wainewright
 |publisher   = [[ZDNet]]
 |date        = 2007-09-06
 |accessdate  = 2007-09-12
 |deadurl     = yes
 |archiveurl  = https://web.archive.org/web/20070908183406/http://blogs.zdnet.com/SAAS/?p=374
 |archivedate = 2007-09-08
 |df          = 
}}</ref>

EditGrid was shut down on May 1, 2014.

== History ==

EditGrid was developed, provided and maintained by [[Team and Concepts]], a [[Hong Kong]]-based company.  The first public [[Beta test|beta]] release of EditGrid was launched on 7 April 2006.  It registered its 10,000th personal user in November 2006.<ref>{{cite web
 |url         = http://www.folknology.com/Exclusive_EditGrid_conversation_with_founder_-_David_Lee.html
 |title       = Exclusive EditGrid conversation with founder - David Lee
 |publisher   = Folknology
 |date        = November 2006
 |accessdate  = 2007-01-15
 |deadurl     = yes
 |archiveurl  = https://web.archive.org/web/20070208033424/http://www.folknology.com/Exclusive_EditGrid_conversation_with_founder_-_David_Lee.html
 |archivedate = 2007-02-08
 |df          = 
}}</ref>  In January 2007 EditGrid started to offer organisation accounts for free trial and also became available on [[Salesforce.com]]'s AppExchange platform.<ref>{{cite web
 |url=http://blog.editgrid.com/archives/178 
 |title=Check out EditGrid at Salesforce AppExchange! 
 |author=David Lee 
 |publisher=EditGrid Developers Blog 
 |date=2007-01-12 
 |accessdate=2007-01-13 
 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070119235944/http://blog.editgrid.com/archives/178 
 |archivedate=2007-01-19 
 |authorlink=David K. F. Lee 
 |deadurl=yes 
 |df= 
}}</ref>  On 14 February 2007,<ref>{{cite web
 |url=http://blog.editgrid.com/archives/200 
 |title=EditGrid Out of Beta, Launched Subscription Service 
 |author=David Lee 
 |publisher=EditGrid Blog 
 |date=2007-02-14 
 |accessdate=2007-02-15 
 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070216062002/http://blog.editgrid.com/archives/200 
 |archivedate=2007-02-16 
 |authorlink=David K. F. Lee 
 |deadurl=yes 
 |df= 
}}</ref><ref>{{cite web
 |url         = http://www.accmanpro.com/2007/02/14/editgrid-out-of-beta/
 |title       = EditGrid out of beta
 |author      = Dennis Howlett
 |publisher   = AccMan
 |date        = 2007-02-14
 |accessdate  = 2007-02-15
 |deadurl     = yes
 |archiveurl  = https://web.archive.org/web/20070216043020/http://www.accmanpro.com/2007/02/14/editgrid-out-of-beta/
 |archivedate = 2007-02-16
 |df          = 
}}</ref> EditGrid officially declared out-of-beta and launched its [[#Subscription service|subscription service]].

In June 2007, EditGrid announced a [[USD|$]]1.25 million [[Venture capital|series A investment]] from the WI Harper Group.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2007/06/10/team-and-concepts-raises-125million-series-a/
 |title=Team and Concepts Raises $1.25million Series A
 |author=Duncan Riley
 |publisher=[[TechCrunch]]
 |date=2007-06-10
 |accessdate=2007-06-14
}}</ref>

EditGrid announced a series of changes to its business in September 2009.<ref name="changes">{{cite web|url=http://blog.editgrid.com/2009/09/24/editgrid-changes-announcement
 |title=EditGrid Changes Announcement
 |author=David Lee
 |publisher=EditGrid Blog
 |date=2009-09-24
 |accessdate=2009-11-12
 |authorlink=David K. F. Lee
}}</ref>
According to the change, they were no longer supporting users through future enhancements or subscription based accounts. The user forum and the wiki have been closed. 
In October 2009 Apple had bought EditGrid.<ref>[http://www.istockanalyst.com/article/viewarticle/articleid/3548218 Apple (AAPL) Acquired EditGrid?]. iStockAnalyst.com. Retrieved on 2013-12-09.</ref><ref>https://angel.co/editgrid</ref>

== Features ==

Touted as the most advanced and well-polished [[Ajax (programming)|Ajax]]-enabled spreadsheet,<ref>{{cite web
 |url         = http://itredux.com/blog/2007/03/26/spreadsheet-roundup/
 |title       = Spreadsheet Roundup
 |author      = Ismael Ghalimi
 |publisher   = ITRedux
 |date        = 2007-03-26
 |accessdate  = 2007-04-18
 |deadurl     = yes
 |archiveurl  = https://web.archive.org/web/20070406221448/http://itredux.com/blog/2007/03/26/spreadsheet-roundup/
 |archivedate = 2007-04-06
 |df          = 
}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.outer-court.com/archive/2007-02-22-n26.html
 |title=EditGrid, Google Spreadsheets Competitor
 |author=[[Philipp Lenssen]]
 |publisher=[[Google Blogoscoped]]
 |date=2007-02-22
 |accessdate=2007-02-23
}}</ref> EditGrid included features for shared access and online [[Collaborative software|collaboration]]<ref>{{cite web
 |url          = http://www.haaretz.co.il/captain/pages/ShArtCaptain.jhtml?contrassID=11&subContrassID=0&itemNo=725095
 |script-title = he:עומדים על נייר
 |author       = ליאור הנר
 |publisher    = [[Haaretz]]
 |date         = 2006-06-09
 |accessdate   = 2006-08-12
 |language     = he
 |deadurl      = yes
 |archiveurl   = https://web.archive.org/web/20060613213406/http://www.haaretz.co.il/captain/pages/ShArtCaptain.jhtml?contrassID=11&subContrassID=0&itemNo=725095
 |archivedate  = 2006-06-13
 |df           = 
}}</ref> on top of conventional spreadsheet functionalities.  Its Real-Time Update (RTU) feature allowed multiple users to see changes on a spreadsheet immediately, and it was considered a winning feature among similar products.<ref>{{cite web
 |url=http://www.inc.com/magazine/20070301/technology-tools_pagen_2.html
 |title=Winning the Numbers Game – Best for... Collaborating
 |author=Michael Fitzgerald
 |publisher=[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc. magazine]]
 |date=March 2007
 |accessdate=2007-04-18
}}</ref>  Its Remote Data feature was able to retrieve live data on the web,<ref>{{cite web
 |url=http://www.networkworld.com/newsletters/web/2006/0717web1.html
 |title=EditGrid, an excellent Web 2.0 spreadsheet
 |author=Mark Gibbs
 |publisher=[[Network World]]
 |date=2006-07-17
 |accessdate=2006-08-11
}}</ref> while its My Data Format (MDF) feature allowed users to customise the output format using [[XSL Transformations|XSLT]], such as live [[Keyhole Markup Language|KML]] for [[Google Earth]].<ref>{{cite web
 |url=http://www.ogleearth.com/2006/08/editgrid_xml_xs.html
 |title=EditGrid => XML + XSLT => KML
 |author=Stefan Geens
 |publisher=Ogle Earth
 |date=2006-08-23
 |accessdate=2006-10-31
}}</ref>  Other features included multiple [[access control]] levels, revision history,<ref>{{cite web
 |url         = http://pcworld.uol.com.br/reportagens/2006/06/29/idgnoticia.2006-06-29.1758689673/IDGNoticia_view
 |title       = Alternativas ao Excel
 |author      = David de Oliveira Lemes
 |publisher   = [[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]
 |date        = 2006-06-29
 |accessdate  = 2006-08-12
 |language    = pt
 |deadurl     = yes
 |archiveurl  = https://web.archive.org/web/20060719063300/http://pcworld.uol.com.br/reportagens/2006/06/29/idgnoticia.2006-06-29.1758689673/IDGNoticia_view
 |archivedate = 2006-07-19
 |df          = 
}}</ref> [[chart]]ing, [[Instant messaging|live chat]], [[permalink]]s and more than 500 spreadsheet functions.

Apart from access from its main site, spreadsheets hosted on EditGrid could be accessed on third-party websites by means of its post-to-[[blog]] feature.

In September 2007, the EditGrid [[iPhone]] Edition was launched at the Office 2.0 Conference.<ref>{{cite web
 |url         = http://blogs.zdnet.com/Howlett/?p=145
 |title       = Spreadsheet for your iPhone
 |author      = Dennis Howlett
 |publisher   = [[ZDNet]]
 |date        = 2007-09-05
 |accessdate  = 2007-09-12
 |deadurl     = yes
 |archiveurl  = https://web.archive.org/web/20070908090130/http://blogs.zdnet.com/Howlett/?p=145
 |archivedate = 2007-09-08
 |df          = 
}}</ref>

In September 2008, EditGrid had launched its [[JavaScript]] [[Macro (computer science)|Macro]] support, enabling user-programmed macros to manipulate EditGrid spreadsheets using JavaScript.<ref>{{cite web
 |url=https://wiki.editgrid.com/display/dev/Macro+Guide 
 |title=Macro Guide - EditGrid Help Centre 
 |publisher=EditGrid 
 |accessdate=2009-05-17 
 |deadurl=yes 
 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081127055031/https://wiki.editgrid.com/display/dev/Macro+Guide 
 |archivedate=2008-11-27 
 |df= 
}}</ref>

== Integration and interoperability ==

EditGrid was available as a module on [[Netvibes]], [[Pageflakes]] and Google Personalized Homepage.<ref>{{cite web
 |url=http://www.webware.com/8301-1_109-9677267-2.html?part=rss&tag=feed&subj=Webware
 |title=EditGrid: A nice competitor to Google Spreadsheets
 |author=[[Rafe Needleman]]
 |publisher=[[CNET]] Webware
 |date=2007-01-11
 |accessdate=2007-01-13
}}</ref>  EditGrid was also available on Salesforce.com's AppExchange platform.

EditGrid also formed part of the offering of [[Central Desktop]],<ref>{{cite web
 |url         = http://blogs.zdnet.com/Orchant/?p=357
 |title       = Central Desktop adds spreadsheets to their mix
 |author      = Marc Orchant
 |publisher   = [[ZDNet]]
 |date        = 2007-02-20
 |accessdate  = 2007-02-21
 |deadurl     = yes
 |archiveurl  = https://web.archive.org/web/20070222055604/http://blogs.zdnet.com/Orchant/?p=357
 |archivedate = 2007-02-22
 |df          = 
}}</ref> [[ShareOffice]]<ref>{{cite web
 |url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/shareoffice_launches.php
 |title=ShareOffice Launches - Open Standards Based Web Office Suite
 |author=Richard MacManus
 |publisher=[[ReadWriteWeb]]
 |date=2007-05-08
 |accessdate=2007-06-14
}}</ref> and [[ThinkFree Office]].<ref>{{cite web
 |url         = http://blogs.zdnet.com/Orchant/?p=465
 |title       = ThinkFree and EditGrid announce online spreadsheet partnership
 |author      = Marc Orchant
 |publisher   = [[ZDNet]]
 |date        = 2007-06-04
 |accessdate  = 2007-06-14
 |deadurl     = yes
 |archiveurl  = https://web.archive.org/web/20070608015444/http://blogs.zdnet.com/Orchant/?p=465
 |archivedate = 2007-06-08
 |df          = 
}}</ref>

In addition, developers could make use of the EditGrid [[application programming interface|API]] to build custom applications.  There were a number of EditGrid [[Plug-in (computing)|add-on]]s that [[Mashup (web application hybrid)|mashed up]] other services.  One of these, Grid2Map, turned longitude-latitude pairs into placemarks on [[Google Maps]].<ref>{{cite web
 |url=http://www.hindu.com/biz/2006/10/30/stories/2006103000651500.htm
 |title=Location-enabled webfeed holds promise
 |author=J. Murali
 |publisher=[[The Hindu]]
 |date=2006-10-30
 |accessdate=2006-10-31
}}</ref>

=== Applications ===
* [http://spreadsheetsgis.googlepages.com/ Spreadsheets KML solutions]
* [http://www.digitalgeography.co.uk/archives/2006/08/online-spreadsheets-and-kml-the-possibilities-are-endless/ Turn online collaborative spreadsheets into live KML]
* [http://seattlefrancophone.info/index.php#charts Historical financial quotes charts with EditGrid]
* [http://simile.mit.edu/wiki/Timeline/EditGrid_XSLT Using EditGrid's XSLT feature to export Timeline XML]

=== Multilingual ===

In addition to the default [[English language|English]] version, EditGrid was available in eight languages: [[German language|German]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[French language|French]], [[Japanese language|Japanese]], [[Dutch language|Dutch]], [[Brazilian Portuguese]], [[Simplified Chinese]] and [[Traditional Chinese]], largely thanks to a community [[Language localisation|localisation]] project.<ref>{{cite web
 |url=http://www.editgrid.com/article/elp
 |title=EditGrid Localisation Project
 |accessdate=2006-11-11
}}</ref>

== Organisation account ==

EditGrid was available to organisation users on a [[software-as-a-service]] basis.  Organisation users were supported by [[Transport Layer Security|SSL]]-encrypted traffic, user account administration and management reports on top of the features available to personal users.<ref>{{cite web
 |url=http://undertheradarblog.com/2007/01/19/its-a-grid-get-it/ 
 |title=It's a grid - get it? 
 |publisher=Under the Radar Blog 
 |date=2007-01-19 
 |accessdate=2007-01-22 
 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070126200024/http://undertheradarblog.com/2007/01/19/its-a-grid-get-it/ 
 |archivedate=2007-01-26 
 |deadurl=yes 
 |df= 
}}</ref>  EditGrid organisation accounts had become completely free-of-charge for all users since September 2009.<ref name="changes" />

== Software architecture ==

EditGrid had been developed on an [[Open-source software|open-source]] software architecture. It ran on [[Catalyst (software)|Catalyst]] as the web application framework and used [[Gnumeric]] as its back-end support. It adopted Ajax technology at the front-end.<ref>http://blog.editgrid.com/?p=21#comment-47</ref>

== References ==
{{reflist|30em}}

== External links ==

<!-- Latest on top -->
* {{Official website|www.editgrid.com}}
* [https://wiki.editgrid.com/ EditGrid Help Centre]

[[Category:Freeware]]
[[Category:Online spreadsheets]]
[[Category:Plotting software]]

pages.title: Expresso spreadsheet
pages.text:
{{Infobox Software
| name                   = eXpresso Spreadsheet Communities
| logo                   = LogoPlain15.jpg
| logo size              = 250px
| screenshot             = 
| caption                = 
| developer              = 
| released               = ?
| programming language   = ?
| operating system       = Any (Web-based application)
| language               = English
| genre                  = Online spreadsheet
| license                = ?
| website                = [http://www.eXpressoCorp.com www.eXpressoCorp.com]
}}
'''eXpresso''' is a hosted workspace for [[Microsoft Office]] communities. [[Microsoft Excel|Excel]] spreadsheet management is the first application offered. It is among the growing number of [[Web 2.0]], [[Software as a service|SaaS]] offerings in the online spreadsheet market. eXpresso serves as a collaborative platform specifically for Excel business users.<ref>{{cite web
|url = http://www.vnunet.com/itweek/news/2193901/expresso-makes-excel-demand
|title = Expresso makes Excel available on demand
|accessdate = 2007-07-10
|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927195235/http://www.vnunet.com/itweek/news/2193901/expresso-makes-excel-demand|archivedate=2007-09-27}}</ref>

== History ==
Exploring Creative Possibilities <ref>{{cite web
|url = http://smallbusiness.itworld.com/4398/nls_itinsights_google060620/page_1.html
|title = eXpressocorp.com - eXpresso Spreadsheet Community
|accessdate = 2006-06-20
|last = Blacharski
|first = Dan
|publisher = ITworld.com
}}</ref> prompted investors to present eXpresso as a standalone product. The free public beta release was introduced in August 2007.

== Features ==
The eXpresso service featured Version Control, Compare, Cell Watch and integrated online chat tools. The Compare feature allows two spreadsheets to be viewed side-by-side with differences highlighted and color-coded by type of change: formula or value.<ref>{{cite web
|url =http://www.crunchbase.com/company/expresso
|title = Companies > eXpresso
|publisher = CrunchBase
}}</ref>

Cell Watch automatically sends an email when a designated cell value or formula is changed by a member of the community. Details of all spreadsheet changes by itself are  recorded and become permanently attached to the document to provide an audit trail.

=== Excel only ===
eXpresso is exclusively designed to support Excel and does not offer a generic or browser-based spreadsheet {{Vague|date=February 2009}}. Excel users can optionally download and install an add-in called ''eXpresso Add-In for Excel'' which allows upload, open and edit eXpresso spreadsheets from Excel. Further the add-in allows spreadsheets to be taken offline to perform work on it independent of an Internet connection.

=== Integration and interoperability ===
eXpresso is available on Salesforce.com's AppExchange platform.<ref>{{cite web
 |url=http://www.salesforce.com/appexchange/detail_overview.jsp?id=a0330000004jVmYAAU
 |title=eXpresso for Salesforce.com's AppExchange
 |publisher=[[Salesforce.com]] AppExchange
 |date=2008-01-16
 |accessdate=2008-01-16
}}</ref>

=== Patents ===
eXpresso has multiple pending patents on its underlying technology. It transforms Excel data and creates a series of related database structures (tables) for data, cell references, formulas, macros, and formats. It then performs the specified operations on data, structure and formulas before reassembling the result and presenting it back in native Excel.

== Subscriptions ==
Pricing is based on a subscription model which includes a free version for light users or individuals. The user agreement shows that it is presently in Version 1.0 beta. It has a 10 Mb space limit per user license without charge.

== Security ==
All user levels are protected by secure servers and strict password authorization.

== References ==
{{reflist}}

[[Category:Collaboration]]
[[Category:Online spreadsheets]]

pages.title: IRows
pages.text:
<!-- Commented out: [[Image:Irows screenshot.png|right|250px|thumb|iRows screenshot]] -->{{lowercase|title=iRows}}
'''iRows''' was a [[World Wide Web|web]]-based [[spreadsheet]] in [[beta test|beta]] with a [[GUI]] similar to the traditional desktop-based spreadsheet applications, such as [[Microsoft Excel]] and [[OpenOffice.org]]. It was shut down on December 31, 2006, after it was announced that its two founders had been hired by [[Google]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2006/11/15/google-absorbing-irows/ |title=Google Absorbing iRows |author=[[Michael Arrington]] |work=[[TechCrunch]] |date=November 15, 2006 |accessdate=2007-04-03}}</ref>

iRows used [[Ajax (programming)|Ajax]] and [[XML]]. It was described as an example of a [[Web 2.0]] system.

iRows supported conventional spreadsheet features functions, value formatting and charts and added web oriented spreadsheet capabilities like collaboration (multiple people using a shared spreadsheet, sending a spreadsheet as a link instead of an attachment and ability to publish spreadsheets on other web pages (e.g. blogs).

==See also==
{{portal|Software}}
* [[List of acquisitions by Google]]
* [[List of online spreadsheets]]

==References==
{{reflist}}

==Further reading==
* {{cite web | url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/11/17/google_irows/ | title=Google draws in iRows | website=The Register | date=November 17, 2006 | accessdate=June 4, 2012 | author=Fay, Joe}}
* O'Reilly, Dennis (August 23, 2006). [https://www.pcworld.com/article/126809/web_spreadsheets_nearly_ready_for_prime_time.html Web Spreadsheets Nearly Ready for Prime Time], [[PC World (magazine)|PC World]] Magazine.

pages.title: IWork
pages.text:
{{lowercase}} {{Infobox software | name = iWork | logo = [[File:IWork Logo.png|150px]] | screenshot = {{aligned table|cols=2 |[[File:Pages 5.6.1.png|132px]] |[[File:Numbers 3.6.1.png|132px]] |[[File:ICloud Homepage.png|132px]] |[[File:Keynote 7.0.5.png|132px]] }} | caption = iWork suite, clockwise from top left: [[Pages (word processor)|Pages]], [[Numbers (spreadsheet)|Numbers]], and [[Keynote (presentation software)|Keynote]] on [[macOS]], and [[ICloud#iWork for iCloud|iWork for iCloud]] in [[Safari (web browser)|Safari 9]]. | author = [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] | developer = [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] | released = {{start date and age|2005|01|11}}{{cite web | title = Apple Unveils iWork '05 | publisher = Apple Press | date = January 11, 2005 | url = https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2005/jan/11iwork.html | accessdate = 2014-04-20 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110329021623/https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2005/jan/11iwork.html | archivedate = March 29, 2011 | df = }} | latest release version = Pages 8.0, Numbers 6.0, Keynote 9.0.1 ([[MacOS]]) Pages 5.0.1, Numbers 5.0.1, KeyNote 5.0.1 ([[IOS]]) | latest release date = {{start date and age|2019|03|28}} | operating system = [[macOS]], [[iOS]]{{cite web|url=http://support.apple.com/kb/SP676|title=iWork System Requirements}} | genre = [[Office suite]] | license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]]
[[Freeware]] and [[Commercial software|commercial]] | programming language = [[Objective-C]], [[C (programming language)|C]], [[JavaScript]] | platform = [[Intel]]
[[ARM architecture|ARM]] ([[Apple A4|A4]] to [[Apple A8|A8]])
[[PowerPC]] (until 2009) | website = {{url|www.apple.com/pages/|Pages}}
{{url|www.apple.com/numbers/|Numbers}}
{{url|www.apple.com/keynote/|Keynote}} }} '''iWork''' is an [[office suite]] of applications created by [[Apple Inc.]] for its [[macOS]] and [[iOS]] [[operating system]]s, and also available cross-platform through the [[iCloud]] website. It includes [[Keynote (presentation software)|Keynote]], a [[presentation program]]; the [[word processor|word processing]] and [[desktop publishing]] application [[Pages (word processor)|Pages]];{{cite web | title = Apple Unveils Keynote | publisher = Apple Press | date = January 7, 2003 | url = https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2003/jan/07keynote.html | accessdate = 2014-04-20 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110414072745/http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2003/jan/07keynote.html | archivedate = April 14, 2011 | df = }} and the [[spreadsheet]] application [[Numbers (spreadsheet)|Numbers]]. It is generally viewed as a [[prosumer]] office suite targeted at home and small business users, with fewer features than competitors such as Microsoft's [[Office for Mac]] and the open source [[LibreOffice]] project (and indeed its own earlier versionshttps://arstechnica.com/apple/2013/11/review-the-productivity-suite-formerly-known-as-iwork/), but has a simpler user interface, strong [[touchscreen]] support and built-in links with Apple's iCloud document-hosting service and its Aperture and [[iPhoto]] image management applications. Apple's design goals in creating iWork have been to allow Mac users to easily create attractive documents and spreadsheets, making use of macOS's extensive font library, integrated spelling checker, sophisticated graphics APIs and its [[AppleScript]] automation framework. The equivalent [[Microsoft Office]] applications to Pages, Numbers, and Keynote are [[Microsoft Word|Word]], [[Microsoft Excel|Excel]], and [[PowerPoint]], respectively.{{cite web | url=http://www.techrepublic.com/article/office-vs-iwork-which-performs-best-in-the-real-world/ | title=Office vs. iWork: Which performs best in the real world? | work=[[TechRepublic]] | date=21 July 2014 | accessdate=22 July 2014 | author=Eckel, Erik }} Although Microsoft Office applications cannot open iWork documents, iWork applications can export documents from their native formats (.pages, .numbers, .key) to Microsoft Office formats (.docx, .xlsx, .pptx, etc.) as well as to PDF files. The oldest application in iWork is Keynote, first released as a standalone application in 2003. Pages was released with the first iWork release in 2005; Numbers was added in 2007 with the release of iWork '08. The next release, iWork '09, also included access to [[iWork.com]], a beta service that allowed users to upload and share documents, now integrated into Apple's [[iCloud]] service. An iOS port was released in 2010 with the first [[iPad]] and has been regularly updated since. In 2013, Apple released a new OS X version and iWork for iCloud, a set of cross-platform web applications replicating the native software versions. iWork was initially sold as a suite for $79, then later at $19.99 per app on OS X and $9.99 per app on iOS. Apple announced in October 2013 that iOS devices purchased from September 2013 onwards and OS X computers purchased from October 2013 onwards,{{cite web | url=https://www.apple.com/creativity-apps/mac/up-to-date/ | title=Up-to-Date Program for Pages, Numbers, and Keynote | publisher=Apple | date=October 22, 2013 | accessdate=December 25, 2013}} whether new or refurbished, are eligible for a free download of all three iWork apps. iWork for iCloud, which also incorporates a document hosting service, is free to all holders of an [[iCloud]] account. Then, in April, 2017, they released the suite, free for macOS and iOS. In September 2016, Apple announced that the real-time collaboration feature will be available for all iWork apps.[[IWork#cite note-32|[32]]] ==History== The first version of iWork, iWork '05, was announced on January 11, 2005 at the [[Macworld/iWorld|Macworld Conference & Expo]] and made available on January 22 in the [[United States]] and worldwide on January 29. iWork '05 comprised two applications: Keynote 2, a presentation creation program, and Pages, a word processor. iWork '05 was sold for US$79. A 30-day trial was also made available for download on Apple's website. Originally [[IGG Software]] held the rights to the name ''iWork''.{{Cite web|publisher=[[MacDailyNews]]|url=http://macdailynews.com/2005/01/03/igg_software_changes_name_of_iwork_to_ibiz/|title=IGG Software changes name of ‘iWork’ to ‘iBiz’ – clearing the way for Apple’s iWork?|date=January 3, 2005}}{{cite news | last = Fried | first = Ina | title = Evidence of shift by Apple / Company possibly developing own office software | url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2005/01/05/BUGK2AL5R51.DTL | accessdate =March 1, 2009 | date = January 5, 2005 | work=The San Francisco Chronicle}}{{cite web | title = Apple to Announce 'iWork' Office Suite? | url = http://daringfireball.net/2005/01/iwork | accessdate =March 1, 2009 | date = January 3, 2005}} While iWork was billed by Apple as "a successor to [[AppleWorks]]", it does not replicate AppleWorks's [[database]] and drawing tools.{{cite web|url=http://www.myfirstmac.com/index.php/mac/articles/an-introduction-to-bento-the-missing-database-app-iwork-should-have|title=An Introduction to Bento, the Missing Database App iWork Should Have}} However, iWork integrates with existing applications from Apple's [[iLife]] suite through the Media Browser, which allows users to drag and drop music from [[iTunes]], movies from [[iMovie]], and photos from [[iPhoto]] and [[Aperture (software)|Aperture]] directly into iWork documents. iWork '06 was released on January 10, 2006 and contained updated versions of both Keynote and Pages. Both programs were released as [[universal binary|universal binaries]] for the first time, allowing them to run natively on both PowerPC processors and the Intel processors used in the new [[iMac]] desktop computers and [[MacBook Pro]] notebooks which had been announced on the same day as the new iWork suite.{{cite web|url=https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2006/jan/10iwork.html|title=Apple Announces iWork '06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110329021622/https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2006/jan/10iwork.html|archivedate=2011-03-29|df=}} The next version of the suite, iWork '08, was announced and released on August 7, 2007 at a special media event at Apple's campus in [[Cupertino, California|Cupertino]], [[California]]. iWork '08, like previous updates, contained updated versions of Keynote and Pages. A new spreadsheet application, Numbers, was also introduced. Numbers differed from other spreadsheet applications, including [[Microsoft Excel]], in that it allowed users to create documents containing multiple spreadsheets on a flexible canvas using a number of built-in templates.{{cite web | title = Apple Introduces iWork '08 | publisher = Apple Press | date = August 7, 2007 | url = https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2007/08/07iwork08.html | accessdate = 2014-04-20 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110515071158/http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2007/08/07iwork08.html | archivedate = May 15, 2011 | df = }} iWork '09, was announced on January 6, 2009 and released the same day. It contains updated versions of all three applications in the suite. iWork '09 also included access to a beta version of the [[iWork.com]] service, which allowed users to share documents online until that service was decommissioned at the end of July 2012. Users of iWork '09 could upload a document directly from Pages, Keynote, or Numbers and invite others to view it online. Viewers could write notes and comments in the document, and download a copy in iWork, [[Microsoft Office]], or [[PDF]] formats.{{cite web|url=https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2009/01/06iwork.html|title=Apple Unveils iWork '09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110630082642/http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2009/01/06iwork.html|archivedate=2011-06-30|df=}} iWork '09 was also released with the Mac App Store on January 6, 2011 at $19.99 per application, and received regular updates after this point, including links to [[iCloud]] and a high-DPI version designed to match Apple's [[MacBook Pro]] with [[Retina Display]].{{cite web|last=Loyola |first=Roman |url=http://www.macworld.com/article/145941/2010/01/iwork_ipad.html |title=Apple introduces iWork for iPad |publisher=Macworld |date= |accessdate=December 31, 2011}} On January 27, 2010, Apple announced iWork for [[iPad]], to available as three separate $9.99 applications from the [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]].{{cite press release|url=https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2010/01/27ipad.html|title=Apple Launches iPad|publisher=[[Apple Inc.|Apple]]|date=January 27, 2010|accessdate=January 27, 2010}} This version has also received regular updates including a version for pocket [[iPhone]] and [[iPod touch]] devices, and an update to take advantage of Retina Display devices and the larger screens of recent iPhones. On October 22, 2013, Apple announced an overhaul of the iWork software for both the Mac and iOS. Both suites were made available via the respective App Stores. The update is free for current iWork owners and was also made available free of charge for anyone purchasing an OS X or iOS device after October 1, 2013.{{cite web|title=Apple - Creativity and Productivity Apps|url=https://www.apple.com/creativity-apps/mac/|accessdate=11 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510043351/http://www.apple.com/creativity-apps/mac/|archivedate=10 May 2014|df=}} Any user activating the newly free iWork apps on a qualifying device can download the same apps on another iOS or OS X device logged into the same App Store account. The new OS X versions have been criticized{{cite web|url=http://www.macrumors.com/2013/10/25/some-power-users-are-unhappy-with-lost-features-in-the-new-iwork/|title=Some Power Users Are Unhappy With Lost Features in the New iWork |publisher=MacRumors |date=October 25, 2013}} for losing features such as multiple selection, linked text boxes, bookmarks, 2-up page views, mail merge, searchable comments, ability to read/export [[Rich Text Format|RTF]] files, default zoom and page count, integration with [[AppleScript]]. Apple has provided a road-map for feature re-introduction, stating that it hopes to reintroduce some missing features within the next six months. As of April 1, 2014 a few features—e.g., the ability to set the default zoom—had been reintroduced, though scores had not. In October 2014, writer [[John Gruber]] commented on the numerous font handling problems that "it's like we're back in 1990 again."{{cite web|title=About the new iWork for Mac: Features and compatibility|url=http://support.apple.com/kb/HT6049?viewlocale=en_GB&locale=en_GB|publisher=Apple|accessdate=6 November 2013}}{{cite web|last1=Gruber|first1=John|title=Twitter post|url=https://twitter.com/gruber/status/524429992487583744|website=Twitter|accessdate=24 December 2014}} Due to using a completely new file format that can work across macOS, Windows, and in most [[web browser]]s by using the online iCloud web apps, means versions of iWork beginning with iWork 13 and later do not open or allow editing of documents created in versions prior to iWork 09, with users who attempt to open older iWork files being given a pop-up in the new iWork 13 app versions telling them to use the previous iWork 09 (which users may or may not have on their machine) in order to open and edit such files. Accordingly, the current version for OS X (which was initially only compatible with [[OS X Mavericks]] 10.9 onwards) moves any previously installed iWork 09 apps to an iWork 09 folder on the users machine (in /Applications/iWork '09/), as a work-around to allow users continued use of the earlier suite in order to open and edit older iWork documents locally on their machine.{{cite web|url=http://www.infoworld.com/article/2610821/open-source-software/open-document-standards-will-cure-apple-s-bit-rot.html|title=Open document standards will cure Apple's bit rot|publisher=Infoworld|first=Simon|last=Phipps|date=March 21, 2014|accessdate=November 23, 2014}} In October 2015, Apple released an update to mitigate this issue, allowing users to open documents saved in iWork '06 and iWork '08 formats in the latest version of Pages.http://appleinsider.com/articles/15/10/15/apple-updates-iwork-for-ios-and-os-x-el-capitan-with-support-for-multitasking-3d-touch-more In 2016, Apple announced that the real-time collaboration feature will be available for all iWork apps, instead of being constrained to using [[iWork for iCloud]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.apple.com/iwork/ |title=iWork |website=Apple |language=en-US |access-date=2016-11-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070814024014/http://www.apple.com/iwork/ |archivedate=2007-08-14 |df= }} The feature is comparable to [[Google Docs, Sheets and Slides|Google Docs]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2016/09/07/apple-adds-real-time-collaboration-to-iwork/|title=Apple adds real-time collaboration to iWork|website=Engadget|access-date=2016-11-27}}{{Cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2016/09/07/apple-iwork-update/|title=Apple adds real-time collaboration to iWork, taking a stab at Microsoft and Google|last=Flynn|first=Kerry|website=Mashable|access-date=2016-11-27}} ==Versions== ===Major releases=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! iWork version !! OS X 10.5.6 "Leopard"]] or newer; released August 26, 2010) * [https://support.apple.com/kb/DL1435 iWork 9.0.4] (for Mac OS X 10.5.6 "Leopard" or newer; released August 26, 2010) *
